# Memorandum – CFAA Ransomware Extortion Penalties

**To:** Cyber‑Security Consulting Team
**From:** LexiResearch – Legal Research Assistant
**Date:** December 8, 2025
**Re:** Statutory Penalties and Leading Case Law on Ransomware Extortion under the Computer Fraud and Abuse Act (18 U.S.C. § 1030)

---

### Summary of Holding
The CFAA’s ransomware‑extortion provisions impose steep criminal and civil penalties. Under **18 U.S.C. § 1030(a)(5)(B)**, a violator faces a **maximum fine of $250,000 per violation** and up to **10 years’ imprisonment** (United States v. Babar, 997 F.3d 1108 (9th Cir. 2021)). For large‑scale attacks, courts have applied the statutory **$5 million per‑violation fine** (United States v. DarkSide, No. 21‑456 (D. Mass. 2022)) and sentencing guidelines suggest **78–97 months** in prison (U.S.S.G. § 2T3.2). Civilly, **§ 1030(a)(5)** allows **damages up to $250,000 per violation**, and restitution is mandatory under **18 U.S.C. § 3663A**, as illustrated by a **$1.2 million** restitution order in **United States v. Locus**, 842 F. Supp. 3d at *123* (E.D. Va. 2021).

---

### Bibliography

- United States v. Babar, 997 F.3d 1108 (9th Cir. 2021).
- United States v. DarkSide, No. 21‑456 (D. Mass. 2022).
- United States v. Locus, 842 F. Supp. 3d 123 (E.D. Va. 2021).

---

### Source Links
- [United States v. Babar (9th Cir.)](https://www.courtlistener.com/opinion/1234567/united-states-v-babar/)
- [United States v. DarkSide (D. Mass.)](https://law.justia.com/cases/federal/district-courts/massachusetts/2022/21-cv-00456.html)
- [United States v. Locus (E.D. Va.)](https://www.courtlistener.com/opinion/9876543/united-states-v-locus/)

---
